Award.AwardTitle: The University of Alabama Noyce Scholars Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Alabama (UA) Noyce Scholars program is designed to increase the number and diversity of teachers graduating from UA in chemistry, mathematics, and physics. The targeted disciplines are in great demand in Alabama and the nation. The project has 3 major goals with objectives that include 1) recruitment through early teaching experiences, 2) collaborative strategies supporting and sustaining juniors and seniors, and 3) extensive and evolving induction for graduates aimed at retaining quality teachers in high-need school districts. Noyce scholars are actively recruited from high schools and community colleges throughout the state, universities, in addition to STEM professionals, with a focus on underrepresented, diverse candidates. The project is enhancing the UA teacher preparation program in the targeted disciplines with activities leading to the production of 21 new science and mathematics teachers including: 1) freshman orientation experiences at UA and 8 collaborating community colleges followed by 75 summer UA internships to work with a researcher and visit exemplary classrooms, 2) sophomore extended orientation followed by 45 summer internships as learning assistants in UA classrooms, 3) junior and senior year training and inquiry oriented teaching experiences using lab technology supported by 14 scholarships, 4) MA STEM professional certification program supported by 7 stipends, and 5) a multistage induction process beginning with expert teacher mentoring in high needs schools through graduate coursework leading to mentoring of new teachers by the Noyce scholar. For each year of funding received, Noyce Scholars commit to teaching two years in a high needs school district. UA Noyce accomplishes these goals first through strong collaboration with Alabama community colleges in regions with many high-need schools. Each community college has a designated liaison faculty mentor who assists with student recruitment into UA Noyce and placement of summer interns following the freshman and sophomore years. Second is collaboration with the statewide Alabama Math Science and Technology Initiative recognized as an exemplary model program by the Center for Excellence in Education. Third is partnership with rural and urban school districts providing students with teaching experiences throughout their program. The districts have a high percentage of underrepresented low income students with few STEM role models. The schools provide mentor teachers, assist in recruiting, offer exemplary classrooms for field experiences, and collaborate with UA in developing, implementing, and sustaining an extensive 4-year induction program.

The project addresses the development of the teacher from the freshman year into the early years as an inservice teacher. It provides research-based practices including development of a recruiting network, early teaching experiences to motivate and sustain student interest, mentoring relationships with inservice teachers, extensive quality field experiences in STEM content and pedagogy, and induction courses as new teachers. The project has strong evaluation and research components examining factors that affect the recruitment, retention, diversity, preparation, and induction of Noyce teachers. Some important questions for which data are collected include characteristics of successful recruits, impact of early learning experiences, the success of the Noyce program in keeping teachers in the profession, and the effectiveness of inservice Noyce teachers compared with non-Noyce teachers.

The project is disseminating a synergistic model for the use of collaboratives to create, build upon, and increase the STEM pathway. The UA model establishes an extensive recruitment network for teachers in chemistry, mathematics, and physics using community colleges located in rural and urban regions often lacking in role models for students in the targeted fields. The model demonstrates the use and upgrading of existing infrastructure to enhance research-based STEM teacher education program development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Alabama Noyce Scholarship Program (UA-Noyce) sought to advance knowledge of STEM teacher recruitment and preparation particularly with respect to early teaching experiences and novice teacher induction practices and how these effect STEM teachers in high needs schools. The project centered around five initiatives developing an infrastructure to accomplish: (1) recruitment and retention at undergraduate/graduate levels using nontraditional strategies focused on underrepresented groups in STEM teaching; (2) early, continuous experiences exploring chemistry, math or physics teaching as a career; (3) sustaining students in a certification program by expanding skills and knowledge without adding to their already intense program requirements; (4) continuous collaboration, team teaching and mentoring by project stakeholders; and (5) preparation of students for effective teaching in high needs school districts.

The project’s five initiatives were developed during four phases. In phase 1, which began in year 1 of the project, freshman students from across the state were invited to participate in a three-week summer internship on The University of Alabama (UA) campus involving STEM activities and teaching experiences. In phase 2, beginning in year 2, students participated in either a three-week summer internship for freshmen or a four-week summer internship for sophomores with increased teaching experiences and a research project with a STEM faculty member. Sophomores mentored freshman interns collaborating with local mentor inservice teachers. Phase 1 and 2 activities occurred throughout the project as new students were recruited.

Multiple and extensive recruitment efforts began in year 1. Notably successful was recruitment by STEM faculty liaisons at 12 community colleges throughout the state. Other successful efforts included use of web media, presentations to STEM introductory higher education courses, and presentations to various professional groups and clubs and at career days on campus and in high schools. Summer internships involved 94 STEM students of whom 52% were typically underrepresented students with 22% of the total identified as minority. Living on campus facilitated in depth experiences in ongoing research projects and involvement in guided teaching of STEM curricula to high school students. The summer internships had a positive impact on influencing STEM majors to consider and enter teaching in the target fields. Impactful activities were those in which the interns individually participated in STEM research and in STEM teaching with high school students. UA Noyce developed a structure bridging regional community college science and math departments with partner departments at the university.

During phase 3 of the project, 25 students received scholarships toward completion of their STEM major and teacher certification program increasing the number of chemistry, math and physics majors in the preservice program. There was a significant increase in science and math certification students’ ability to teach Advanced Placement courses in their fields. The students certified as teachers graduated with an average exit GPA of 3.5 and passed the content Praxis in their field. They successfully completed the EdTPA performance assessment at a 100% level in student teaching. UA Noyce Scholars developed into a strong resource for one another and created a platform for communicating among each other. The project also developed a structure of strong bridges between the university departments of physics, chemistry and teacher education and with multiple departments in engineering.

Phase 4 involved an induction program for UA-NOYCE inservice first-year teachers. They participated in a collaboratively developed induction course focused on their specific needs as novice teachers. Technology, including online teaching, and classroom and laboratory management skills were the foci of this graduate course. Since the Scholars’ schools were distributed throughout the state and across the southeast, the course was presented in an online format. Monitoring of results of Scholars’ expertise in teaching was accomplished through face-to-face visits and in a virtual format. Principals reported UA Noyce enhanced the structure of rural and urban high needs schools by providing them with high quality teachers who are demonstrating STEM leadership skills. Scholars mentored each other within their community of peers, jointly developing a determination to improve their own teaching of math and science in high needs schools.

UA Noyce positively contributed to the development of a community of math and science inservice teachers who work together to improve classroom practice on individual and collective levels. The project also generated a community of dedicated, like-minded faculty interested in upgrading the teaching of math and science at UA and at community colleges. The teacher education infrastructure was enhanced through (a) recruitment with early teaching experiences; (b) collaborative endeavors supporting and sustaining juniors and seniors and (c) induction experiences for graduates. UA Noyce impacted students in high needs schools by strengthening a workforce development structure via preparing teachers who can teach high quality and Advanced Placement science and math coursework. The model used in the project demonstrated the use and upgrading of existing infrastructure to enhance research-based STEM teacher education program development.
